items.title: eLife enhances open annotation with Hypothesis to promote scientific discussion online
items.impactStatement: The open-source Hypothesis software has been extensively customised for use by eLife and other publishers, with new features giving publishers more control over its implementation on their sites.

items.title: Study suggests new approach for targeting cancer-causing protein, RAS: attack from outside the cell
items.impactStatement: Attacking mutated RAS proteins on cancer cells from the outside-in could be a viable therapeutic approach for previously ‘undruggable’ cancer targets.

items.title: Mosquito bite frequency influences malaria spread
items.impactStatement: New study suggests variation in the frequency of mosquito bites within regions and even households is likely to play a key role in the success of malaria control efforts.

items.title: Can we develop new topical drugs by learning how our skin communicates with the nervous system?
items.impactStatement: Researchers shed new light on the communication between our skin, nerve cells and brain that gives us our sense of touch.

items.title: Genetic analysis predicts future threat from MERS virus
items.impactStatement: While Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) does not appear to present an imminent global threat, researchers encourage continued genomic surveillance of the virus.

items.title: eLife welcomes early-career researcher to its Board of Directors
items.impactStatement: The new board member will help oversee the strategic direction of eLife and support the organisation in its mission.

items.title: Study finds cancer cells manipulate fat metabolism for survival
items.impactStatement: Discovery of new survival strategy in tumour cells reveals potential drug target for future cancer treatments.

items.title: New insight into unique plant chemical could inform future drug development
items.impactStatement: Study addresses the question of how natural plant chemicals called glucosinolates evolve the ability to interact with genes in humans.

items.title: Live 3D imaging highlights cellular activity during embryonic heart development
items.impactStatement: Imaging technique reveals three phases of heart-tube formation in mouse embryos, and could help increase our understanding of normal heart development and how abnormalities occur in newborns.

items.title: Scientists show migration boosts survival in songbirds
items.impactStatement: Study provides important new insights on the evolution of migration in blackbirds.

items.title: New gene expression analysis paves way for improved disease diagnosis and treatment
items.impactStatement: Study provides new insight on the deficiency of a biological process called oxidative phosphorylation and could aid in future diagnosis and treatment strategies.

items.title: eLife welcomes the Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation as a new funder-partner
items.impactStatement: Leading Swedish research funder joins nonprofit coalition.

items.title: New model of newborn gut development reveals crucial role of microbiota
items.impactStatement: A new system reproduces the physiology of the immature human intestine, enabling research into a range of host-microbe interactions to understand their role in health and disease.

items.title: Slight electrical brain stimulation strengthens human memory
items.impactStatement: Evidence that low-current electrical stimulation can enhance our memory could pave the way for treating patients with chronic memory impairment.

items.title: eLife welcomes new Chair of its Early-Career Advisory Group
items.impactStatement: The new Chair will help ensure the voice of junior researchers continues to be heard within the organisation.

items.title: eLife and Collaborative Knowledge Foundation partner to deliver open-source submission and peer-review platform
items.impactStatement: The new platform will help streamline communications between authors, editors and reviewers at all stages of the submission and review process.

items.title: eLife supports development of open technology stack for publishing reproducible manuscripts online
items.impactStatement: The Reproducible Document Stack will ultimately allow authors to submit their manuscripts in a format that includes embedded code blocks and computed outputs, and for publishers to preserve these assets in an enhanced version of the published online article.

items.title: Intensive workouts boost children’s brains
items.impactStatement: A new study reveals that short bursts of high-intensity exercise can improve working memory and cognitive control in children.

items.title: Gut microbes influence life expectancy
items.impactStatement: Researchers reveal that transplanting gut bacteria from young African turquoise killifish into middle-aged fish increases the longevity of these animals, presenting a potential new intervention to enhance lifespan in other organisms.

items.title: Major database mining project seeks to improve drug side effect reporting
items.impactStatement: New research shows that while FAERS provides a solid frame for reporting, it also contains redundancies and biases that affect the ability to analyse and interpret the data.

items.title: Heartbeats could hold key to understanding babies’ inner world
items.impactStatement: A novel experiment reveals that babies as young as five months old are aware of their own heartbeats.

items.title: Knee joint signals bones to grow
items.impactStatement: Researchers suggest neighboring cells in nearby joints help control bone growth in mice.

items.title: eLife joins Substance Consortium to support development of open-source online content-editing tools
items.impactStatement: By joining the consortium, eLife will support the introduction of innovative new tools to help expand the current online open scholarly infrastructure.

items.title: Availability of open reference data nears 50% as major societies and influential publishers endorse the Initiative for Open Citations
items.impactStatement: In the three months following the Initiative for Open Citations' launch, the percentage of articles with open reference data has moved from 40% to over 45%.

items.title: Insect ‘anti-antiaphrodisiac’ tells males when females are ready to mate
items.impactStatement: Scientists discover a pheromone released by female plant bugs that counters the effects of an antiaphrodisiac found in the male's semen.

items.title: Hormonal changes during early development limit lifespan in mice
items.impactStatement: Researchers discover early exposure to growth hormone negatively impacts lifespan, particularly in males.

items.title: ScienceFair: new desktop app with eLife Lens helps research and discovery continue offline
items.impactStatement: ScienceFair allows users to access and consume science from their desktop using peer-to-peer technology.

items.title: New results from cancer reproducibility project released
items.impactStatement: The assessment of eLife editors is that the new studies from the Reproducibility Project: Cancer Biology have reproduced important parts of the original papers.

items.title: Scientists capture first images of shortest non-repetitive genome sequence in 3D
items.impactStatement: A research team has pushed the ability of a molecular diagnostic technique to image a specific segment of the genome in super resolution.

items.title: eLife improves online reading for scientists with modern user experience design
items.impactStatement: The new eLife website uses the latest in web design to deliver the best possible reading experience for users across multiple devices – and the code is completely open.

items.title: Humans rely more on ‘inferred’ visual objects than ‘real’ ones
Metabolic markers accurately diagnose typhoid fever
Viral fossils reveal how our ancestors may have eliminated an ancient infection
Legionella bacteria’s escape route revealed
Initiative for Open Citations (I4OC) launches with early success
items.impactStatement: There is fresh momentum in the scholarly publishing world to open up data on the citations that link research publications.

items.title: 'Flying syringes' could detect emerging infectious diseases
Fruit flies halt reproduction during infection
We collect ORCIDs from authors of accepted papers at proofing
items.impactStatement: Collecting ORCIDs at an early stage supports our efforts to simplify the authentication process.

items.title: Scientists find genetic mutations that drive antibiotic resistance
How habitat destruction figures in long-term survival plans
Scientists reveal how the brain maintains useful memories
Scientists identify two brain networks influencing how we make decisions
Habitat features and social behaviour impact how baboons move as a group
Dyslexia linked to shorter memory trace of previous stimuli
First results of cancer reproducibility project released
items.impactStatement: The first five papers from the Reproducibility Project: Cancer Biology are part of an effort to study reproducibility in this field in a transparent way.

items.title: Risk of tree species disappearing in central Africa ‘a major concern’, say researchers
Amazonia's best and worst areas for carbon recovery revealed
New footprints hint at early human ancestor’s social behaviour
items.impactStatement: Footprints discovered in Tanzania give new insight into our ancient ancestor, Australopithecus afarensis, the same species as the famous fossil Lucy.

items.title: Ants communicate by mouth-to-mouth fluid exchange
items.impactStatement: The process in ants of transferring fluids to each other mouth-to-mouth is more than just a means of food-sharing.

items.title: Protein and salt drive post-meal sleepiness
items.impactStatement: High levels of protein and salt in our food can cause longer naps after eating.

items.title: New protein provides critical link between aging and age-dependent disease
Scientists ‘plug in’ to circuitry behind sex in male fruit flies
How fake hand foxes brain
items.impactStatement: Researchers explain the changes that occur in the brain during the rubber hand illusion, creating a feeling of disembodiment from the hand.

items.title: Females react differently than males to social isolation
Diabetes opens floodgates to fructose
Overlooked plants defy drought
eLife partners with Hypothes.is to advance open scholarly annotation
items.impactStatement: The move will bring publishers and researchers an open annotation platform to create annotations for personal use, or as part of conversations with private groups or the general public.

items.title: Surprise discovery in the blink of an eye
How sleep deprivation harms memory
HIV is not a super-spreader of drug-resistant tuberculosis
Echo templates aid mental mapping in bats
Dutch men and Latvian women tallest in world according to 100-year global height study
items.impactStatement: The largest ever height study provides substantial insight into the global heights of young adult men and women between 1914 and 2014.

items.title: Travel broadens chimps' horizons too
items.impactStatement: Researchers discover that travel fosters greater tool use for foraging in chimpanzees.

items.title: How birds unlock their super-sense, ultraviolet vision
New brainstem model reveals how brains control breathing
Insights into the neurons that cause symptoms of Rett syndrome could guide search for new therapies
Scientists reveal sub-Saharan Africa’s legacy of past migrations over last 4,000 years
New plant engineering method could help fill demand for crucial malaria drug
Research funders renew commitment to transforming science publishing
items.impactStatement: Non-profit eLife receives a second round of funding.

items.title: Flatworms left in sunlight spur investigations into rare metabolic disorders
eLife welcomes new member to its Board of Directors
items.impactStatement: eLife's new board member will direct the initiative in its aim to help scientists accelerate discovery by reshaping science publishing.

items.title: Study suggests new treatment for seizures
Threat of novel swine flu viruses in pigs and humans
Where next for Zika virus?
items.impactStatement: A study led by the University of Oxford maps the global environmental suitability for the spread of Zika virus.

items.title: Double advantage of potential new diabetes treatment
Tropical birds develop ‘superfast’ wing muscles for mating, not flying
Deadly flatworm’s skin rejuvenation may explain its long-term survival in humans
Scientists reveal how animals find their way ‘in the dark’
Complex learning dismantles barriers in the brain
items.impactStatement: Intensive training in a complex task can overcome the divisions of the separate areas in our brain dedicated to specific senses.

items.title: Similarities in fruit fly nervous systems transform view of metamorphosis
Groundbreaking text mining project highlights ‘gender gap’ in scientific research
items.impactStatement: An analysis of 15,000 mouse studies showed that around half of them failed to report the sex and age of the animals involved, highlighting the issue of reproducibility in scientific research.

items.title: Drug-resistant genes spread through environment, not meat products
Scientists uncover history of ancient viruses as far back as 30 million years ago
Studies explain adolescents’ vulnerability to addictive drugs
Slime can see
items.impactStatement: Researchers reveal that bacterial cells act as the equivalent of a microscopic eyeball or the world’s oldest and smallest camera eye.

items.title: Scientists’ robotically driven system could reduce cost of discovering drug and target interactions
Scientists create imaging ‘toolkit' to help identify new brain tumour drug targets
Scientists prove key aspect of evolutionary theory
Study illuminates new design strategies for optogenetic tools
Being anxious could be good for you -- in a crisis
items.impactStatement: Researchers identify for the first time specific regions of the brain involved in the apparent 'sixth sense' we have for danger.

items.title: Generous mothers receive less nagging
items.impactStatement: In social species, such as mice and humans, mothers will be nagged less by their offspring if they are already generous providers.

items.title: Could 2016 be a bad year for the malaria parasite in Africa?
Midnight munchies mangle memory
items.impactStatement: Researchers discover that eating late at night can negatively impact learning and memory.

items.title: "Hunger hormone" is boosted by restricted meal times
items.impactStatement: Scientists identify how the hunger hormone ghrelin allows rats to eat more when faced with restricted feeding schedules.

items.title: Scientists warn light pollution can stop coral from spawning
items.impactStatement: Researchers discover that exposure to artificial light hinders reproduction in coral.

items.title: Golden discovery of novel imaging technique captures beauty of metal-labeled neurons in 3D
Hummingbirds rely on raw power, not physique, to outmanoeuvre rivals
First insights into changes to developing brain caused by gene associated with autism
New test for ancient DNA authenticity throws doubt on Stone Age wheat trade
Early hospitalisation key to survival for Ebola victims in the Democratic Republic of the Congo
